findings.title: Hardcoded Secrets in Code Examples
findings.description: The instruction body contains hardcoded sensitive credentials in code examples, including a database password ('P@ssw0rd123!') and an API key ('sk_live_abc123xyz'). While these appear to be example values for demonstration purposes, including literal secrets in documentation creates security risks: users may copy-paste these examples without changing credentials, developers may accidentally commit real secrets following this pattern, and it normalizes hardcoding secrets in code. Best practice is to use placeholder values like '<your-password-here>' or environment variable references.
findings.snippet:
KeyVaultSecret secret = secretClient.setSecret("database-password", "P@ssw0rd123!");
...
KeyVaultSecret secretWithOptions = secretClient.setSecret(
    new KeyVaultSecret("api-key", "sk_live_abc123xyz")
findings.remediation: Replace all hardcoded credential values with placeholders (e.g., '<your-database-password>', '<your-api-key>') or references to environment variables. Add explicit warnings in documentation that example credentials must never be used in production. Consider using clearly fake formats like 'example_password_replace_me' to make it obvious these are not real credentials.

metadata.overall_assessment: This Azure Key Vault Secrets Java SDK skill is primarily a documentation/reference package with MEDIUM security concerns. The main issue is hardcoded example credentials in code samples (database password and API key), which could lead to credential exposure if users copy-paste without modification. The skill has no executable scripts, reducing attack surface significantly. Missing optional metadata (license, compatibility, allowed-tools) and a referenced but missing backup.py file are minor documentation issues. The incomplete code example could cause runtime problems. Overall, this appears to be a legitimate Azure SDK documentation skill with documentation quality issues rather than malicious intent, but the hardcoded credentials pattern should be addressed to prevent accidental credential exposure.
metadata.meta_confidence_reason: LLM analyzer correctly identified hardcoded example credentials. While this is a documentation skill (not executable code), the pattern could lead to credential exposure if users copy examples without modification.
metadata.meta_exploitability: Low - Requires user to copy-paste examples without changing credentials
metadata.meta_impact: Medium - Could lead to credential exposure in production if pattern is followed
